{{Other people|Edward Boyd}} [[Image:Eddie-Boyd-Top-L copy.jpg|thumb|200px|right]] '''Edward Riley Boyd''' known as '''Eddie Boyd''' (November 25, 1914 – July 13, 1994)[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p284/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography] was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[piano]] player, born on Stovall's Plantation near [[Clarksdale, Mississippi|Clarksdale]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 94–95 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} ==Life and career== Boyd moved to the [[Beale Street]] district of [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]] in 1936 where he played piano and [[guitar]] with his group, the Dixie Rhythm Boys. Boyd followed the [[great Migration (African American)|great migration]] northward to the factories of [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1941. He [[songwriter|wrote]] and [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] the [[hit song]]s "[[Five Long Years]]" (1952), "24 Hours" (1953), and the "Third Degree" (co-written by [[Willie Dixon]], also 1953). Boyd [[concert tour|toured]] [[Europe]] with [[Buddy Guy]]'s band in 1965 as part of the [[American Folk Blues Festival]]. He later toured and recorded with [[Fleetwood Mac]] and [[John Mayall and the Bluesbreakers]]. Tired of the [[racial discrimination]] he experienced in the [[United States]], he first moved to [[Belgium]] where he recorded with the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[band (music)|band]], [[Cuby and the Blizzards]]. He settled in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] in 1970, where he recorded ten blues [[Gramophone record|records]], the first being ''Praise to Helsinki'' (1970). He married his wife, Leila, in 1977. Boyd died in 1994 in Helsinki, Finland, just a few months before [[Eric Clapton]] released the [[record chart|chart-topping]] blues [[album]], ''[[From the Cradle]]'' that included Boyd's "Five Long Years" and "Third Degree". ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Eddie Boyd and His Blues Band featuring [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]]'' – [[Decca Records|Decca]] (1967) with the Bluesbreakers; CD release on Gott Discs #"Too Bad, Pt. 1" #"[[Dust My Broom]]" #"Unfair Lovers" #"[[Key to the Highway]]" #"Vacation from the Blues" #"Steakhouse Rock" #"Letter Missin' Blues" #"Ain't Doin' Too Bad" #"Blue Coat Man" #"Train Is Coming" #"Save Her Doctor" #"Rack 'Em Back" #"Too Bad, Pt. 2" #"Big Bell" #"Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" #"[[Night Time Is the Right Time]]" Eddie Boyd : piano, vocals
